node.doctext:
CST review archive 15

This is a storage node for CST reviews. Contents are moved her from [CST_Chat].

This archive begins on 02/27/05, When it's full we'll move to [CST_Storage_16].

See also Quest Storage collabs [CST_Storage_1|1], [CST_Storage_2|2], [CST_Storage_3|3], [CST_Storage_4|4], [CST_Storage_5|5], [CST_Storage_6|6], [CST_Storage_7|7], [CST_Storage_8|8], [CST_Storage_9|9], [CST_Storage_10|10], [CST_Storage_11|11], [CST_Storage_12|12], [CST_Storage_13|13], [CST_Storage_14|14], [CST_Storage_15|15].

-- Batch Processed on 27 February 2005 by gom --

Writeup Title: [American Underworld Dictionary]
Author: [pukesick]
Reviewer: [GrouchyOldMan]
Public domain?: Yes, Copyright lapsed
Original Author's Permission received?: No
Quoted content less than 33%: No
Compliance Assessment: Yes
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes: 2005.2.19 (6.3 hr) mauler says What is the copywrite status of pukesick's entries from the American Underworld Dictionary (1950)?
As of 22 Feb 2005, searches of the Library of Congress copyright database indicate that the copyright on this work has indeed lapsed allowing it to enter the public domain. Until proven otherwise, it's [CST Approved].
Tc = 2295, Tq = 2285, %q= 99%

Author: [wharfinger]
Reviewer: [GrouchyOldMan]
Public domain?: No
Original Author's Permission received?: No
Quoted content less than 33%: No
Compliance Assessment: No
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes: 2005.2.19 (6.3 min) JohnnyGoodyear says People Power in the Disco Hour. And don't think the Wharf is coming back, I'm afraid to day, as regards fixing it. JG
Hi there, Bad news I'm afraid. This writeup doesn't appear to be compliant with the [E2 FAQ: Copyrighted Material|E2 Copyright Policy] and has been removed from the database. If you'd like to add more original content and repost I'd be glad to assist you with copyright compliance.
Tc = 383, Tq = 246, %q= 64%

Writeup Title: [A Christmas Tsunami Lament]
Author: [teos]
Reviewer: [GrouchyOldMan]
Public domain?: No
Original Author's Permission received?: Yes, permission granted in person to the noder.
Quoted content less than 33%: No
Compliance Assessment: Yes
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes: 2005.-0.2- at 17: 1 teos says Please review my E2 Scratch Pad, which will shortly (post-approval) be noded as A Christmas Tsunami Lament. Thanks
Hi there, if you've received permission from the Pastor, then you can tag this as [CST Approved] when you post it, as long as you explain that permission was granted at the bottom.
NOTE: Reviewed on [Teos]' scratchpad.

Writeup Title:[One Fine Day]
Author:[TheLady]
Reviewer: [Lometa]
Public domain?: No.
Original Author's Permission received?: No.
Quoted content less than 33%: 65%
Compliance Assessment: No.
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes: 2005.2.14@0:25 [GrouchyOldMan] says 2005.2.13 (4.4 min) [JohnnyGoodyear] says Baas: [One fine day]?
Hello TheLady, Unfortunately because of the [E2 copyright changes] E2 can no longer host copyrighted lyrics unless they meet fair use. If you are interested in updating this you may want to read through [E2 FAQ: Copyrighted Material] for some suggestions or ideas. If you need any help or have questions please feel free to message me. If I don’t hear from you by next [February 22,2005|Tuesday] I will have to remove the write up.
2005.2.16@9:14 [TheLady] says Thanks Lometa, you can go ahead and delete it. I haven't really got much to say about it beyond what's there, which probably means I don't like it as much as I thought anyway!

Hello JediBix783, Unfortunately because of the [E2 copyright changes] E2 can no longer host copyrighted lyrics unless they meet fair use. If you are interested in updating this you may want to read through [E2 FAQ: Copyrighted Material] for some suggestions or ideas. If you need any help or have questions please feel free to message me. If I don’t hear from you by next [February 22,2005|Tuesday] I will have to remove the write up.
Removed because of the [E2 copyright changes].

Writeup Title: [Shortest science fiction story ever]
Author: [Vorbis]
Reviewer: [GrouchyOldMan]
Public domain?: No
Original Author's Permission received?: Yes, per an included copyright statement
Quoted content less than 33%: No
Compliance Assessment: Yes
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes: 2005.-0.2- at 11: 1 Vorbis says Please review Shortest science fiction story ever for copyright compliance.
*Groan* Well, maybe this is compliant by the letter of the law, but it would be much improved if you added a little more context. Even a few more bio sentences would help, e.g. why would Blake care to do this and what makes him think this is a "science fiction story" anyway?
Vorbis says re Shortest science fiction story ever : I wanted to keep the /wu as short as possible so as not to ruin the joke. Shouldn't bio information belong to the Michael Blake node? I think that Blake labeled it a SF story because of its reference to telepaths... I really don't know why Blake cared to write this story. It can be found in a couple of important collections, though (I read it in an old Urania ).
Okay, your call. So, it is technically compliant and you can add the CST_Approved tag if you wish. Looks like the votes are punishing it a bit tho and if you want it removed to stop the pain lemme know. Cheers.
Tc = 59, Tq = 4, %q= 7%

Hi there, Bad news I'm afraid. This writeup doesn't appear to be compliant with the [E2 FAQ: Copyrighted Material|E2 Copyright Policy]. You need more original content to qualify under [fair use]. If you'd like to update it for compliance and repost, I'd be glad to advise and assist.
Tc = 4414, Tq = 4400, %q= 99%

Writeup Title:[eye contact at a distance]
Author:[mellamaphone]
Reviewer: [Lometa]
Public domain?: No.
Original Author's Permission received?: No.
Quoted content less than 33%: 100%
Compliance Assessment: No.
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes:2005.2.7@21:25 [Pint] says a heads up: check out [mellamaphone]'s writeup in [eye contact at a distance] - Liff seems to be freely available all over the net in various forms, but no copyright info is available.
Hello mellamaphone, Unfortunately this excerpt from Douglas Adams’ [The Meaning of Liff] is under copyright and can no longer be kept in the database. If you would like to update it you may want to read through the [E2 FAQ: Copyrighted Material] for some suggestions and ideas. If you have any questions please feel free to ask,otherwise it will have to be removed from E2 by next [February 17, 2005|Thursday].
2005.2.13@5:29 [mellamaphone] says re: [eye contact at a distance] - consider it [deleted|done]! Thanks for the msg.

Writeup Title:[Rez Rocket]
Author:[gleeme]
Reviewer: [Lometa]
Public domain?: No.
Original Author's Permission received?: No.
Quoted content less than 33%: 20%/54%
Compliance Assessment: Yes. Quoted poster is cited as “Author unknown” at all websites accessed via Google search on February 10, 2005.
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes: ) 2005.2.2@21:52 [wertperch] says [Rez Rocket] has been referred to me...
Hello [gleeme], As long as I’ve lived in AZ I’ve never heard of this term, but can readily identify one now that I’ve read about it! This has been reviewed by the [CST_Group] and is compliant. If you would like to you may append this hardlink [CST Approved] .

Writeup Title: [TiHKAL]
Author: [in10se]
Reviewer: [GrouchyOldMan]
Public domain?: No
Original Author's Permission received?: Yes, per an included copyright statement
Quoted content less than 33%: No
Compliance Assessment: Yes
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes: 2005.-0.2- avalyn says Seems that the PiKHAL and TiKHAL entries we have here are all ©1997 Alexander Shulgin. Can I get a general concensus on whether they should be deleted or not?
Hi there, this just came under discussion by the CE's regarding copyrights and I've voiced my opinion that you did it right. I added a note to the node and you can add the [CST Approved] tag if you wish.
[in10se] says re: TiHKAL: Thank you. May I do the same for the chapters I have noded so far (EIPT, DPT, and DET)?
you said "Yep, as long as they all have the copyright notice and a reference to the index wu. Cheers." to in10se
Tc = 1850, Tq = 1800, %q= 95%

Reviewer: [GrouchyOldMan]
Public domain?: Yes
Original Author's Permission received?: N
Quoted content less than 33%: No
Compliance Assessment: Yes
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes: 2005.01.31 at 10:01 Pint says do yer thing: Synge and the ireland of his time: preface. There's going to be 16 more of these nodes - you want me to put in requests for each of them as they come up, or no?
Hi there, this writeup has been reviewed for copyright compliance under the [E2 FAQ: Copyrighted Material|E2 Copyright Policy] and is compliant via public domain. If you'd like you can add the [CST Approved] tag just to the index, or to each of the writeups.
Tc = 458, Tq = 450, %q= 99%

Writeup Title:[tract]
Author:[stand/alone/bitch]
Reviewer: [Lometa]
Public domain?: Yes.
Original Author's Permission received?: NA
Quoted content less than 33%: NA
Compliance Assessment: Yes.
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes: 2005.1.27@0:54 [OldMiner] says [stand/alone/bitch]'s [tract] is a poem by William Carlos Williams whose works appear to primarily have been published from 1917 onward. The work may or may not be protected under copyright.
Hello [OldMiner], You’re right, WCW’s [tract] was published in 1917. Anything published prior to 1923 falls into public domain. I added an editorial notation to the write up. Thanks for bringing it to our attention.

Writeup Title:[Houses in the Fields]
Author:[eeyore14]
Reviewer: [Lometa]
Public domain?: No.
Original Author's Permission received?: No.
Quoted content less than 33%: 0%
Compliance Assessment: Yes.
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes:
2005.1.27@6:56 [eeyore14] says I guess I missed [Watch Your Step] when I cleaned up or removed my lyrics nodes long ago. I'll try to fix it, but I won't have time before this weekend. For now I'll remove the section with the lyrics. I accept the need for the policy, but it's always been frustrating to me. All of the lyrics I've ever posted were my interpretation from listening to the recording, not copies of published lyrics. I didn't realize at the time that even that wasn't acceptable. I also removed the lyrics from [Houses in the Fields] and [Comiskey Park Tribute]. I had intended to request permission for those long ago and forgot about them as well.
Hi eeyore14, Thank you for fixing the write-ups so that they are copyright compliant. I evaluated all three and you can append the [CST Apporved|CST Tag] of approval to all three of them. Keep in mind that as long as the lyrics are 250 words or less and are 1/3 or less of the total content they fall under [fair use] and can be on E2. [Comiskey Park] looks like it might comply. If you want to put the lyrics back I would be more than happy to evaluate it for you.

Writeup Title:[Miserlou]
Author:[ Metacognizant]
Reviewer: [Lometa]
Public domain?: No.
Original Author's Permission received?: No.
Quoted content less than 33%: 20% Yiddish; 22%English
Compliance Assessment: Yes.
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes: Metacognizant messaged Content Salvage asking if the lyrics for Miserlou were in public domain since they were first published in the 1940’s. I explained that the cut off date for PD works was 1923. He did a very good job researching some of the background of the song and included a translation both of which meet fair use guidelines. Well done!

Writeup Title: [Ten reasons why creation scientists don't believe in evolution]
Author: [everyone], originally [Nafal]
Reviewer: [GrouchyOldMan]
Public domain?: No
Original Author's Permission received?: Requested
Quoted content less than 33%: No
Compliance Assessment: Yes, pending a reply from the original author
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes: This was originally a C&P writeup by [Nafal] who has apparently left E2. Since the rest of the node hinges on the arguments here, I took on the responsibility of reauthoring it to the [everyone] account, and seeking permission from the original author to reproduce it here. I contacted the author (Doug LaPointe) in February 2005 with my request and info about E2. To date I haven't received a reply, but the work has been widely quoted and posted on other websites and, absent a response from the author, I'm insuring its presence in the database. If the author complains, we'll have to remove it immediately. For the time being, it's tentatively [CST Approved]

-[GrouchyOldMan]

Reviewer: [Lometa]

Original Author's Permission received?: Yes.

Compliance Assessment: Yes.
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes: 2005.3.19@15:54 [Lometa] says, Hello [sekicho], Unfortunately the citation by U2 exceeds the content by just a bit-36%. You may want to add a few words to make it copyright compliant. Just something simple will do like listing the sources. Are the lyrics yours? If so you may want to note that as well so that others don’t think it’s under copyright and keep turning it into [Content_Salvage].
At 37% the quote in this write up still exceeds the 33% requirement for copyright compliance. If you are interested in updating this you may want to read through [E2 FAQ: Copyrighted Material] for some suggestions or ideas. If you need any help or have questions please feel free to message me. If I don’t hear from you by next [March 27th|Sunday] I will have to remove the write up.

2005.3.2sekicho says something about it being a “PARODY”
Even parodies are subject to copyright. I think my question about the sources needs to be answered. The quote in particular that is attributed to Bono is that [really] something he said or did you make it up?
2005.3.20@19:34 [sekicho] says Do you think Bono would have performed a song that I made up?
2005.3.20@19:35 [sekicho] says Especially considering that I would have been 3 years old at the time?
I have no idea how old you are and I have no idea if the quote is something you used as an inspiration to create the lyrics from. [Sundae, Bloody Sundae] has been reviewed by the [CST_Group] and is compliant. You may append this hardlink [CST Approved] . Thank you.

2005.3.18@21:04 [Posmella] says Regarding [Two Word Poem] and Content Salvage: I haven't been able to make contact with the publishers yet. I'll have one more go, and failing that will try to think of a way to make it policy acceptable. ^_^ Is that OK?
Fair enough. Does two weeks sound like a reasonable length of time to get permission or update the write up to meet copyright compliance?
2005.3.18@21:15 [Posmella] says *grimaces* I'll give it a shot; if I'm running short of time, however, I may attempt to negotiate! *grins* Thanks.
